importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: China expanded export controls on 12 of 17 rare-earth metals and certain refining equipment, effective December 1, in response to US trade restrictions.
President Donald Trump announced a 100% tariff on Chinese goods, effective from November 1, in retaliation for China's rare earth export controls.
Trump and Xi Jinping are expected to meet in South Korea during the APEC summit, with the trade dispute raising concerns about diplomatic outcomes.
Former President Joe Biden tightened US controls on microchip exports to China, restricting access to advanced semiconductor tools and equipment.
Biden restricted US exports of advanced computer chips to China and other countries, targeting AI and military-related technologies.
Biden introduced export controls on semiconductors and semiconductor manufacturing equipment, blocking access to US technology and tools.
Trump imposed sweeping 25% tariffs on Chinese goods, escalating the US-China trade conflict and prompting retaliatory tariffs from China.
Trump introduced 10% tariffs on Chinese products, later increased to 25% in May 2019, as part of a broader trade policy targeting China.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from May 2024 to October 2025 marks a cycle of trade retaliation, tariff reductions, and renewed tensions between the US and China, with both sides engaging in tit-for-tat measures.
The current escalation in trade tensions is occurring in the lead-up to the US-China meeting at the APEC summit in South Korea, raising expectations for diplomatic resolution or further escalation.

keyTakeAways: The US and China are engaged in a renewed trade dispute, with Trump threatening a 100% tariff on Chinese goods in response to China’s export controls on rare earth minerals.

China claims its export restrictions are a response to US targeting of Chinese firms and sectors, including maritime and shipbuilding industries, and that US actions violate trade norms and national security principles.
Rare earth minerals are critical for technologies such as electric vehicles, smartphones, and semiconductors, giving China a strategic economic and technological advantage.
China’s export controls, introduced on October 9, 2025, are seen as 'pre-meeting choreography' to gain leverage ahead of the US-China summit in South Korea.
The US has a history of aggressive trade measures, including 25% tariffs in 2018 and 145% tariffs in 2024, which have been met with reciprocal tariffs from China, including a 125% tariff.
Both nations have expanded the definition of national security to include economic and technological policies, leading to accusations of mutual weaponization of economic interdependence.
Experts note that the US has more strategic leverage due to its larger domestic market, while China is better prepared and more strategic in its responses.
The ongoing trade conflict risks reigniting a broader trade war, increasing global economic uncertainty and impacting global supply chains and technology development.
Trump’s 100% tariff threat and China’s rare earth controls reflect a deepening geopolitical rivalry where economic tools are used as instruments of national strategy.
The upcoming meeting in South Korea may serve as a potential turning point, but both sides appear to be retaining escalation tools, suggesting a cautious, high-stakes diplomatic approach.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former and current US President; central figure in the threat of a 100% tariff on Chinese goods and the broader trade conflict with China.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is the political leader driving the US response to China’s export controls with a 100% tariff threat, making him central to the current escalation of the trade war.

namedEntities.name: Xi Jinping
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of China; central figure in China’s response to US trade policies and in diplomatic negotiations with Trump.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Xi is the counterpart to Trump in the diplomatic context, and China’s actions—such as rare earth export controls—are framed as strategic moves ahead of their meeting in South Korea.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The People's Republic of China; major economic power and leader in rare earth production and export controls.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China's rare earth export restrictions are central to the trade dispute, and its actions are viewed as a strategic response to US trade and technology restrictions.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The United States; global economic and technological superpower with aggressive trade policies toward China.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US is the primary target of China's export controls and has responded with a 100% tariff threat, showing the core of the trade conflict between the two global powers.

namedEntities.name: Rare Earth Metals
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A group of critical minerals essential for high-tech manufacturing and defense industries.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China's near-monopoly on rare earths gives it strategic leverage, and export controls on these metals are central to the trade dispute and global technology supply chain.

namedEntities.name: TikTok
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global social media platform owned by ByteDance, a Chinese company.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US government’s attempt to ban TikTok or require a non-Chinese ownership reflects broader national security concerns about Chinese tech influence.

namedEntities.name: Huawei
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Chinese multinational technology company, leader in 5G networks.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Huawei was targeted by US sanctions for alleged national security threats, illustrating the use of trade and technology policies as tools of geopolitical competition.

namedEntities.name: United States Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A US federal agency responsible for regulating trade and technology exports.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It played a key role in enforcing export controls on semiconductors and advanced chips, particularly under the Biden administration.

namedEntities.name: US Vice President JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A political figure and spokesperson for the US government on trade policy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vance stated that the US has more leverage than China, reflecting internal US government views on the trade conflict.

namedEntities.name: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A senior US official involved in economic policy and trade diplomacy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He confirmed that Trump’s tariffs would not take effect before November 1 and expressed confidence in the upcoming meeting with Xi Jinping.

namedEntities.name: World Trade Organization (WTO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international organization that sets trade rules and resolves disputes among nations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: In 2012, the WTO ruled that China’s rare earth export restraints were unfair and breached trade rules, highlighting past disputes over export controls.

namedEntities.name: India
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global economy and key observer of US-China competition in the Indo-Pacific region.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Indian experts like Manoj Kewalramani critique the weaponization of economic policies and emphasize the mutual strategic depth of the US-China rivalry.

namedEntities.name: Japan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key economic and technological partner in the Indo-Pacific region.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Japan is mentioned in the context of trade and security dynamics, especially in relation to US-China competition and technological supply chains.

namedEntities.name: Europe
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A collective economic bloc that has previously joined complaints about China’s rare earth controls.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The European Union and US jointly complained to the WTO in 2012, showing the broader international dimension of the trade conflict.

namedEntities.name: South Korea
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A regional host country for the upcoming US-China meeting.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The meeting between Trump and Xi is scheduled to take place in South Korea during the APEC summit, making it a critical diplomatic venue.

namedEntities.name: Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A regional economic forum that includes US and Chinese participation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The APEC summit hosts the scheduled meeting between Trump and Xi, framing the current trade dispute as a potential diplomatic flashpoint.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article outlines the escalating trade conflict between the United States and China, centered on China’s expansion of export controls on rare earth minerals in response to US trade restrictions and targeting of Chinese firms. US President Donald Trump responded with a threat of a 100% tariff on Chinese goods, effective November 1, 2025, further heightening tensions. The dispute stems from a history of tit-for-tat tariffs, including Trump’s 25% and 145% tariffs in previous years and Biden’s export controls on semiconductors and advanced chips. Both nations have broadened the definition of national security to include economic and technological activities, leading to accusations of mutual weaponization. The situation is set to be resolved or further escalated at an upcoming meeting in South Korea during the APEC summit. Experts note that while the US has greater economic leverage, China is more strategically organized, and the conflict reflects a deeper geopolitical rivalry where economic tools are used for national security and strategic advantage.
title: Trump’s 100% tariff threat: History of US trade measures against China
